ARTICLE.TITLE: The four Conservative MP rebels who deserve praise for helping Hull in the past
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Sign up to the Hull Live newsletter for daily updates and breaking news Sign up here! Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Invalid Email

It's been a toxic week in British politics.

Not only has new Prime Minister Boris Johnson suffered an unprecedented hat-trick of voting defeats in the House of Commons but he's also removed the whip from 21 Tory MPs, effectively sacking them on the spot.

Among those getting their marching orders were four who I've interviewed over the years during ministerial visits to Hull.

Each one was up here to oil the wheels of big projects which would ultimately rely on government backing to become a reality.

I spent a windy morning on the Humber Bridge with Justine Greening discussing how another chunk of its historic debt was being written off, allowing crossing tolls to be cut by half.

It was an early big win for the coalition government and attracted cross-party support. Those were the days.

(Image: PA)

Wind also featured on the agenda whenever Greg Clark was in town.

He was a key player in ensuring the Siemens Gamesa offshore wind turbine factory eventually got built on Alexandra Dock as part of the Green Port Hull initiative and really seemed to grasp the whole concept of turning the city into a green energy hub.

As an aside, he also possessed the largest pair of ministerial hands I've ever shaken. They are huge.

(Image: PA)

Philip Hammond was here in his days as transport secretary, meeting council and business leaders to discuss the seemingly never-ending topic of congestion on Castle Street and how to deal with it.

It was during his visit that I also first became aware of his unlikely connection with deputy Labour city council leader Daren Hale, who is distantly related to him by marriage.

Hammond almost certainly started the ball rolling on making a fresh case for Castle Street to the Treasury.

The fact that work on the the long-awaited Castle Street upgrade is finally due to start late next year once the new footbridge is in place over Hull's busiest road simply underlines just how long these things take.

(Image: PA)

Ed Vaizey proved to be an enthusiastic champion of Hull's 2017 City of Culture bid.

When he came here in 2015, we had already won the race for the title and preparations were starting to shift into gear.

In a city centre bar, he spoke with the conviction of someone with a genuine passion for the arts and in stark contrast to the likes of Karen Bradley and Matt Hancock who would follow him as culture secretary.

(Image: newcastle chronicle)

Today all four are facing uncertain futures.

Greening has announced she's standing down at the next general election, Vaizey and Hammond appear to determined to stand again while Clark has yet to reveal his very large hand.

Some will argue the same quartet were also part of successive governments responsible for austerity, the bedroom tax and giving the green light for a certain referendum of the UK's future relationship with the European Union.

But whatever your politics might be, all four at least deserve some praise for the parts they also played in supporting a city not known for having a groundswell of Tory voters and helping deliver big changes on the ground.
